user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 14.3 is: Controlling expressions shall not be invariant.
Here are exceptions to this rule:
1. Invariants that are used to create infinite loops are permitted.
2. A do-while loop with an essentially Boolean controlling expression that evaluates to false and satisfies the constraints and semantics for an integer constant expression is permitted.
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of answer_unique_dyn_response:
```c
static enum MHD_Result
answer_unique_dyn_response (void *cls,
                            struct MHD_Connection *connection,
                            const char *url,
                            const char *method,
                            const char *version,
                            const char *upload_data,
                            size_t *upload_data_size,
                            void **req_cls)
{
  static int marker = 0;
  struct MHD_Response *r;
  enum MHD_Result ret;
  (void) cls;  /* Unused */
  (void) url; (void) version; /* Unused */
  (void) upload_data; (void) upload_data_size; /* Unused */

  if (NULL == *req_cls)
  {
    /* The fist call */
    *req_cls = (void *) ▮
    /* Do not send reply yet. No error. */
    return MHD_YES;
  }
  if ((0 != strcmp (method, MHD_HTTP_METHOD_GET)) &&
      (0 != strcmp (method, MHD_HTTP_METHOD_HEAD)))
    return MHD_NO; /* Unsupported method, close connection */

#if MHD_VERSION >= 0x00097701
  r = MHD_create_response_from_buffer_static (body_dyn_size,
                                              body_dyn);
#else  /* MHD_VERSION < 0x00097701 */
  r = MHD_create_response_from_buffer (body_dyn_size,
                                       (void *) body_dyn,
                                       MHD_RESPMEM_PERSISTENT);
#endif /* MHD_VERSION < 0x00097701 */
  ret = MHD_queue_response (connection, MHD_HTTP_OK, r);
  MHD_destroy_response (r);
  return ret;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function answer_unique_dyn_response:
#define MHD_HTTP_METHOD_GET "GET"
...
#define MHD_HTTP_METHOD_HEAD "HEAD"
...
#define MHD_VERSION 0x01000100
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
suspicious_frags:
if ((0 != strcmp (method, MHD_HTTP_METHOD_GET)) &&
      (0 != strcmp (method, MHD_HTTP_METHOD_HEAD)))
    return MHD_NO; /* Unsupported method, close connection */

#if MHD_VERSION >= 0x00097701
  r = MHD_create_response_from_buffer_static (body_dyn_size,
                                              body_dyn);
#else  /* MHD_VERSION < 0x00097701 */
  r = MHD_create_response_from_buffer (body_dyn_size,
                                       (void *) body_dyn,
                                       MHD_RESPMEM_PERSISTENT);
#endif /* MHD_VERSION < 0x00097701 */
explanation: I reported all control expressions present in the function: the two runtime if-statements and the compile-time #if/#else/#endif branch. Other parts of the function are not controlling expressions and thus are not relevant to Rule 14.3: variable declarations/initializers (e.g. static int marker = 0), (void) casts for unused parameters, function calls and assignments (MHD_create_response_from_buffer[_static], MHD_queue_response, MHD_destroy_response), and return statements are not control expressions that could be invariant under Rule 14.3. There are no loops (for/while/do-while) or switch statements in the function beyond the listed fragments, so no additional control expressions need investigation for invariance.
